<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 221, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 213, 678]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 280, 918, 313]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows parts of the curves with equations \(y=4 \mathrm{e}^{-2 x}\) and \(y=1+0.5 \sin 3 x\). Point \(P\) is a point of intersection of the curves, and the shaded region is bounded by the two curves and the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 328, 136, 340]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 328, 826, 344]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) satisfies the equation \(x=-0.5 \ln (0.25+0.125 \sin 3 x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 328, 866, 340]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 545, 136, 557]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 918, 593]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in part (a), to find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) correct to 4 significant figures. Use an initial value of 0.5 and give the result of each iteration to 6 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 390, 89]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[360, 102, 639, 120]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{p}(x)=a x^{4}+b x^{3}+13 x^{2}-35 x+15,
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 135, 770, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((2 x-1)\) and \((x-3)\) are factors of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 167, 366, 183]]<|/det|>
